data.title: Redesign Of StorageDevice
data.body:
As part of working to support [Microsoft's .NET Native](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/vstudio/dotnetnative) i'm looking at incompatibilities that we need to resolve.

Some of these issues are with the following APIs:
- [StorageDevice.BeginOpenContainer](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.storage.storagedevice.beginopencontainer.aspx)
- [StorageDevice.EndOpenContainer](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.storage.storagedevice.endopencontainer.aspx)
- [StorageDevice.BeginShowSelector](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.storage.storagedevice.beginshowselector.aspx)
- [StorageDevice.EndShowSelector](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.storage.storagedevice.endshowselector.aspx)

The issue with them is the use of `AsyncCallback` and `IAsyncResult` which is unsupported in .NET Native.

We need to decide how to modify, remove, and/or replace these with modern equivalents.

data.title: Fix WM_QUIT drain in TestGameBase
data.body:
According to MSDN, WM_QUIT causes GetMessage to return 0. Checking for
this fixes a hang issue when running the tests for the Windows build of MonoGame on
Windows 8.1.

Remove unused code from Texture2D.DirectX and do a minor tidy up

Fixes #2306

Removed the MONOMAC regions.
Removed the extra way to load in PlatformFromStream.
Did a minor tidy up on CreateTex2DFromBitmap / LoadBitmap (including whitespace).

data.title: Documentation Project
data.body:
This is the first commit of the documentation project for MonoGame.
- Uses [SharpDoc](https://github.com/xoofx/SharpDoc) as the generator.
- We build class reference for both the framework and the new pipeline.
- Generator currently runs for windx, wingl, win8store, wp8, linux, and web.
- Copied over existing documentation content from website.
- Updated version of Protobuild which supports `<DocumentationFile>`.
- Hooked it up to the build script.

This will be followed by hooking in the rest of the platforms, style sheet improvements, and more content.

data.title: Android sound samples play at wrong speed (unless 44.1Khz)
data.body:
Hi!

Playing android samples which are not 44100 play faster than they should (probably not resampling to 44100, as the lower the sample rate, the faster is played)

data.title: Fix crash in DisposeAll
data.body:
We need to copy this list as disposing items in it causes it to be modified.

This was technically broken before, but disposing resources wouldn't make them get removed from the list. It does now, so this is broken!

Refs #2375

data.title: Add GraphicsDevice.GetBackBufferData and implementations for GL/DirectX

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This allows taking screenshots of your running game!

At the moment the implementation only supports byte[] data and returns the data as RGBA/BGRA 32bit, it could be extended to support more formats.
The format of the pixels differs by platform. XNA and WindowsGL return it in BGRA, WindowsDX, iOS, Android returns it in RGBA.

It should be possible to get WindowsDX to return data in the same format, but this was my first time doing DirectX programming :) (Doing a cpu side swap just so user code can undo it seems wrong)
Android and iOS image code handles RGBA data, so they aren't really an issue.

Only the simplest version of this function is implemented, there are two others which have not been included:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.graphicsdevice.getbackbufferdata.aspx

Tested on iOS, Android, Windows(GL/DX).

I have an example for WindowsDX, WindowsGL, iOS and Android using this here:
https://github.com/danzel/WrapTest/blob/master/WrapTest/WrapTest/Game1.cs#L199-L250
It might be nice to have this example code somewhere, any suggestions?

Fixes #1885

data.title: Added OPENAL definition
data.body: As discussed in #2370

data.title: Implemented basic XmlImporter functionality
data.body:
This covers much of the basic XmlImporter functionality. It supports reading from XML into any custom data type it can find in loaded assemblies. It supports all the integral types, generic collections, and the efficient array format for integers, vectors. It also handles polymorphic types and explicit type specifications for elements.

Also included are XML test data and corresponding classes I've been using to debug it. They're straight out of Sean Hargreaves' [Everything you ever wanted to know about IntermediateSerializer](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2008/08/12/everything-you-ever-wanted-to-know-about-intermediateserializer.aspx). No unit tests yet, but it's a step towards it.

Stuff I haven't implemented yet:
- Custom names for elements
- Flattened content for nested classes
- Shared resources
- External references
- Error checking for elements that are required to be null

Nothing too tough to do, I just ran out of time for now. Later passes can finish off these features. Additionally, if someone needs the IntermediateSerializer, they can refactor this code and create the writing end of it pretty easily.

Note that MonoGame doesn't currently have a ReflectiveWriter so AFAIK custom types will need a ContentTypeWriter defined.

data.title: Fixed Build
data.body:
The PR build of #2372 missed this because the Web platform was added between when it was submitted and when it was merged.  

We need to greatly reduce our open PR count to fix the PR build process to ensure this won't happen again.

data.title: MonoGame Documentation Project
data.body:
This next week we're going to start the documentation project for MonoGame.  I'm writing this here to publicly communicate the plan to the community and get feedback.
## SharpDoc

MonoGame will use [SharpDoc](https://github.com/xoofx/SharpDoc) for generation of class reference documentation as well as organization of hand crafted documentation pages.  I have put up a quick example of SharpDoc results on MonoGame here:

 [http://www.monogame.net/reference/](http://www.monogame.net/reference/)

SharpDoc is created by @xoofx for documenting SharpDX.  You can also see it used there:

 [http://sharpdx.org/documentation](http://sharpdx.org/documentation)
## Reference Docs

The reference docs one part of the documentation process.  Our goal is to surpass the quality of the existing XNA docs by including hints as to the inner implementation of the code as well as platform specific details.  The reference docs should link to or include small code examples when the API usage isn't clear.

Over the next few weeks we will create some documentation examples and tasks for documenting specific classes to help guide contributors as to how to help with the process.
## Manual Docs

The docs that are hand crafted for guides, walkthroughs, detailed system explanations, example code, etc will be authored using Markdown format in a new "Documentation" folder here in the MonoGame repo.  To make changes to the docs one would fork the repo and then either edit locally on their machine or via the Markdown editor built into GitHub.

The benefits of this workflow are:
- Docs are versioned along side the code.
- Thru pull requests we get a chance to evaluate new and changed docs.
- Changes to code functionality can coincide with doc changes within the same PR.

An example of this in practice is how the SharpDX docs are maintained:

  [https://github.com/sharpdx/SharpDX/tree/master/Documentation](https://github.com/sharpdx/SharpDX/tree/master/Documentation)
## Build Process

When we merge code into the develop branch it will kick of documentation generation for both the reference and manual docs on the build server.  The docs will be an artifact of the build just like assemblies and installers.

Then periodically (maybe once a day) we will copy the docs up to the MonoGame site replacing the existing docs with the latest ones.  This will all be automated.

We will probably maintain docs for each shipped release along with docs for the latest 'develop' branch.
## Offline Docs

The docs could also be compiled for offline use either thru a Microsoft Help CHM file, VS2010 style Help 2, or even PDFs.  This is all functionality we would need to cobble together ourselves or add support for it into SharpDoc.

This would be a goal once we get the docs up and running online.

data.title: RFC: Add support for ANGLE platform (take 2)
data.body:
Right now, testing the OpenGL ES codepath of MonoGame requires an valid Xamarin.Android or iOS license. 

This PR adds support for OpenGL ES on Windows via the [ANGLE project](http://code.google.com/p/angleproject/). It is based on the WindowsGL project and reuses the GLES, OpenAL and OpenTK codepaths.

_**Note:** this currently depends on #2359_

While this PR is meant for Windows/ANGLE, it should also work on other OpenGL ES implementations, including OpenGL ES emulators ([PowerVR SDK](http://www.imgtec.com/powerVR/insider/sdkdownloads/index.asp)), desktop OpenGL with `GL_ARB_ES[2|3]_compatibility`, and native Linux OpenGL ES drivers. These implementations have not been tested.

Changes:
- Added MonoGame.Framework.Angle project to Protobuild
- Added new `ANGLE` #define and implemented where necessary (mainly on OpenAL and a few OpenGL ES codepaths)
- Implemented Occlusion Queries via OpenGL ES 3.0. This is currently enabled on ANGLE only, pending further review for ANDROID and IOS.

Pending:
- Add ANGLE binaries to ThirdParty/Dependencies. Is there a preferred way to handle 32-bit and 64-bit native binaries?

This PR has been tested with the Platform2D sample from MonoGame-Samples. Most unit tests appear to run correctly, but my Windows VM runs out of memory before it can complete the test suite.

data.title: RFC: Add support for ANGLE platform
data.body:
Right now, testing the OpenGL ES codepath of MonoGame requires an valid Xamarin.Android or iOS license. 

This PR adds support for OpenGL ES on Windows via the [ANGLE project](http://code.google.com/p/angleproject/). It is based on the WindowsGL project and reuses the GLES, OpenAL and OpenTK codepaths.

_**Note:** this currently depends on #2359_

While this PR is meant for Windows/ANGLE, it should also work on other OpenGL ES implementations, including OpenGL ES emulators ([PowerVR SDK](http://www.imgtec.com/powerVR/insider/sdkdownloads/index.asp)), desktop OpenGL with `GL_ARB_ES[2|3]_compatibility`, and native Linux OpenGL ES drivers. These implementations have not been tested.

Changes:
- Added MonoGame.Framework.Angle project to Protobuild
- Added new `ANGLE` #define and implemented where necessary (mainly on OpenAL and a few OpenGL ES codepaths)
- Implemented Occlusion Queries via OpenGL ES 3.0. This is currently enabled on ANGLE only, pending further review for ANDROID and IOS.

Pending:
- Add ANGLE binaries to ThirdParty/Dependencies. Is there a preferred way to handle 32-bit and 64-bit native binaries?

This PR has been tested with the Platform2D sample from MonoGame-Samples. Most unit tests appear to run correctly, but my Windows VM runs out of memory before it can complete the test suite.

data.title: Changes to GraphicsProfile
data.body:
Some changes to GraphicsProfile. Need testing on other platforms...
_GraphicsDeviceManager.cs_
-GraphicsProfile is initialized with the highest possible value by calling the new static method GraphicsDevice.GetHighestSupportedGraphicsProfile(null);
-[WP8] _graphicsDevice.GraphicsProfile is now updated inside GraphicsDeviceManager.ApplyChanges(...) after deviceCreation like the rest DirectX platforms.

_GraphicsDevice.cs_
-GraphicsProfile is now read only. The correct way to set the profile is: 
1) set graphics.GraphicsProfile inside the Game.actor()
3) change it on GraphicsDeviceManager.PreparingDeviceSettings event
2) set graphics.GraphicsProfile and call graphics.ApplyChanges() after initialization
-Add static GetHighestSupportedGraphicsProfile(GraphicsDevice device) method. 
For DirectX this will return the highest supported Profile based on the device FeatureLevel. When device is null it will query the (slower?) SharpDX.Direct3D11.Device.GetSupportedFeatureLevel(). 
For all other platforms it will return HiDef, which was the current default. Hopefully this will not cause any problems.
-When set GraphicsProfile (internally) it will check if it is supported by the device and throw an Exception on error. 

_GraphicsDevice.DirectX.cs_
-Remove code that set the GraphicsProfile after device creation.

_GraphicsProfile.cs_
Assign values to the enum so it's easier to compare different levels. Also a propose of extending GraphicsProfile with other FeatureLevels.

data.title: RFC: Implement ARB and EXT flavors of FBOs
data.body:
MonoGame is currently relying on GL_ARB_framebuffer_object without explicitly checking for support. This means it will fail to run on systems that do not support OpenGL 3.x+.

This patch implements a fallback to GL_EXT_framebuffer_object when GL_ARB_framebuffer_object is not supported. (Note that we cannot use GL_EXT_framebuffer_object alone, since many systems support the ARB flavor but not the EXT one.)

Changes:
- Added `GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsFramebufferObjectARB` and `GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsFramebufferObjectEXT`
- Added `FramebufferObject`, `FramebufferObjectEXT`, `RenderbufferObject` and `RenderBufferObjectEXT` classes, under `GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.[Framebuffer|Renderbuffer]Object.cs`
- Replaced direct calls to GL.Framebuffer\* and GL.Renderbuffer\* with calls to `GraphicsDevice.Framebuffer.*` and `GraphicsDevice.Renderbuffer.*`

Advantages:
- MonoGame should now run on OpenGL 2.1 cards that do not support GL_ARB_framebuffer_object
- Fewer annoying `#if GLES` regions
- More consistent error checking

Disadvantages:
- The new classes use virtual methods to select the correct implementation during platform setup. This is necessary on desktop platforms. The compiler should be able to remove this on mobile platforms, but it can be explicitly removed if necessary.

There are two alternatives to virtual methods: if-else clauses or delegates. If-else clauses may incur a branch misprediction and delegates consume more memory than virtual methods.

data.title: Audio Cleanup
data.body:
This is just some final audio cleanup, no functional changes.

We now have all sound effect code in the one Audio folder and not spread out all over the code base.

data.title: GamePad Refactor
data.body:
This is a fairly major refactor of the GamePad classes across all platforms.
- Moved all GamePad implementations to the common Input folder.
- Added GamePad.cs with full public API and proper documentation.
- We now use partial classes and private functions to resolve platform code.

There is more work we can do to improve the GamePad classes still.
- #2367 - Implement Common Virtual GamePad
- #2368 - Implement GamePadDeadZone

data.title: Implement GamePadDeadZone
data.body:
Across most the platforms we don't have GamePadDeadZone implemented.

We should implement some common shared code for doing GamePadDeadZone filtering then hook this into all the `GamePad.PlatformGetState` implementations.

data.title: Implement Common Virtual GamePad
data.body:
We need a new virtual GamePad implementation that we can use across multiple platforms.

Currently we have a pretty complete virtual GamePad implemented specifically for iOS.  We should convert that code to use TouchPanel state and be reusable across all touch screen based platforms like Android, Windows Phone, and Windows 8 Store.

The new implementation should be opt-in for these platforms.

data.title: Request: Support for Windows Phone 8.1 App projects
data.body:
Could MonoGame be updated to support Windows Phone 8.1 Apps and Universal apps?

The new projects seem different enough that neither the WP or Win 8 builds will work with the new platform

data.title: WP8 Cannot stop song after deactivate and re-activate
data.body: I have noticed a slight bug on WP8 - you cannot pause or stop or pause a song playing in the mediaplayer upon reactivation. Basically, the song is stopped as expected when the app deactivates, and when it comes back, the song is started and then is moved to the point it was before the deactivation. However, any subsequent calls to the media player in order to stop or pause the song have no effect.

data.title: StorageContainer Player folder accuracy
data.body:
I just pushed this fix to MG-SDL2:

https://github.com/flibitijibibo/MonoGame/commit/677b2d499df34ef99dc7b71ae777ce8085d97dd9
https://github.com/flibitijibibo/MonoGame/commit/241b534767c16b1789972f1447617032513df3d3
https://github.com/flibitijibibo/MonoGame/commit/22d8861589889062788fd4a7d964ae4c9244642d

The problem, in summary (pulled from my G+ post https://plus.google.com/102593483001615978126/posts/7qE6nJGcdL2 ):

"Previously, StorageDevice exhibited the following behavior:
- When opening a StorageContainer with a PlayerIndex, the container created a folder Player0 to Player3, depending on the PlayerIndex.
- When opening a StorageContainer without a PlayerIndex, the container did not create any folder, and simply operated on the game save directory's root folder.

As it turns out, NEITHER of these behaviors are correct! From the 'Implementation on Windows' section of the following MSDN article:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb200105.aspx

'When no PlayerIndex is specified, content is saved in the AllPlayers folder. When a PlayerIndex is specified, the content is saved in the Player1, Player2, Player3, or Player4 folder, depending on which PlayerIndex was passed to BeginShowSelector.'"

For the most part this isn't too big of a deal, but for Windows titles trying to keep XNA compatibility, this essentially breaks save compatibility entirely. The commit above is pretty small as it is, but the main thing to pull from it is the `if (playerIndex.HasValue)` changes.

data.title: MediaPlayer.Volume setter accepts any value
data.body: It's currently possible to crank it up to 11 (110%), or to -Inf if you so choose. We should clamp it to the valid range [0, 1].

data.title: GraphicsProfile is changed upon device reset on Windows Phone 8.1
every frame memory allocation
data.body:
monogame has memory allocation in method Model.Draw in foreach (ModelMesh mesh in Meshes)  each frame enumerator is created.  also in other places, sprites drawing etc.

details:

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/etayrien/archive/2007/03/17/foreach-garbage-and-the-clr-profiler.aspx
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/etayrien/archive/2007/04/19/foreach-and-garbage-part-2.aspx

however, this will not necessarily create performance problems. because garbage collection in 0 generation is quite effective.
